item.description: Biography I am a PhD student in the department of Medical Statistics and Bioinformatics at Leiden University Medical Center. My work is centered around complex time-to-event data, mostly in the field of random effect (frailty models) in survival analysis. In my spare time, I like to put my skills to use for good causes. I am the co-author and maintainer of the R packages frailtyEM and dynfrail.

item.title: Software
item.description: frailtyEM is an R package that may be used for fitting shared frailty models. For a Breslow-type non-parametric baseline hazard, several frailty distributions are supported: gamma, inverse Gaussian, positive stable, PVF-family. Both clustered failures and recurrent events are supported, and prediction curves are easily obtained. The stable version is on CRAN and development version on GitHub. For a more detailed presentation of models and methods, as well as an overview of the implemented estimation approach, I wrote a comprehensive vignette for the package.

item.title: PhD thesis: Advances in frailty models
item.description: What are frailty models? Imagine we have a device that ticks every now and then, and denote the number of ticks up to time $t$ as $N(t)$. Broadly speaking, the goal of survival analysis is to determine the intensity of this process, so as to answer how likely it is that, after observing this device for a while, we would expect another tick to happen in the next period of time.

item.title: frailtyEM (R package)
item.description: frailtyEM is an R package that may be used for fitting shared frailty models. Main features: Breslow-type non-parametric baseline hazard frailty distributions: gamma, inverse Gaussian, positive stable, PVF-family. type of data: clustered failures recurrent events (gap time + calendar time) prediction survival and cumulative incidence curves with confidence bands with ggplot2 and base graphs Upcoming features: fast calculation of the cross ratio function speed improvements fully parametric baseline hazard and flexible parametric baseline hazards Links:
